dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Eight months into this new policy shift, and it's clear the measures aren't enough to stabilize growth at a high enough rate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Eight months into this new policy shift, and it's clear the measures aren't enough to stabilize growth at a high enough rate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, seven months into this shift, it is clear that these new policy measures alone will not be enough to stabilize growth at a sufficiently high rate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're really trying to avoid, um, opening the credit floodgates again like they used to.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're really trying to avoid, um, opening the credit floodgates again like they used to.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Chinas leaders seem to accept that unless there are major negative shocks, they should not open the credit floodgates again to address cyclical weakness.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but that means they've got this incredibly difficult balancing act—keeping growth up for social stability while also, uh, managing the renminbi's exchange rate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but that means they've got this incredibly difficult balancing act-keeping growth up for social stability while also, uh, managing the renminbi's exchange rate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, China must perform a difficult balancing act. It needs to keep growth high enough to maintain social stability, while also maintaining external stability, as reflected in the renminbis exchange rate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is a huge deal globally. I mean, they mention the 1996-1997 Asian crisis as a warning—pegged currencies and debt-driven growth just don't mix well.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is a huge deal globally. I mean, they mention the nineteen ninety six to nineteen ninety seven Asian crisis as a warning-pegged currencies and debt-driven growth just don't mix well.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A central lesson from the 1997-1998 Asian crisis was that rigid exchange rates were incompatible with rapid, debt-driven growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And China's debt-to-GDP ratio, it surged from 145% to 265% in a decade. That's staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And China's debt-to-G D P ratio, it surged from one hundred forty five percent to two hundred sixty five percent in a decade. That's staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, aggregate debt levels surged to around 270% of GDP in 2018 from approximately 150% in 2008.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So now their hands are kind of tied, right? They can't just cut interest rates because they're worried about the currency depreciating.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So now their hands are kind of tied, right? They can't just cut interest rates because they're worried about the currency depreciating.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China currently is unwilling to ease monetary policy because it doesnt want the renminbi to depreciate, in part for geopolitical reasons but also due to its bad experience with currency flexibility in August 2015.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and that reluctance goes back to their bad experience in August 2015 with currency flexibility.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and that reluctance goes back to their bad experience in August twenty fifteen with currency flexibility.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China currently is unwilling to ease monetary policy because it doesnt want the renminbi to depreciate, in part for geopolitical reasons but also due to its bad experience with currency flexibility in August 2015.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But the article points out debt-service costs are now equivalent to 70% of monthly credit flow—like, interest rate cuts are becoming urgent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the article points out debt-service costs are now equivalent to seventy percent of monthly credit flow-like, interest rate cuts are becoming urgent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, following the sharp rise in debt over the last decade, debt-service costs are now equivalent to 70% of the total monthly flow of credit. Interest-rate cuts have become imperative.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And if they don't ease monetary policy, they could fall into the same trap as other Asian economies did in the '90s.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And if they don't ease monetary policy, they could fall into the same trap as other Asian economies did in the '90s.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If China fails to ease monetary policy to complement the fiscal stimulus, it risks falling into a trap similar to the one that ensnared its Asian peers in the 1990s.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a real tightrope walk. Plus, all these uncertainties—Western trade challenges, risk-averse lenders shunning private borrowers...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a real tightrope walk. Plus, all these uncertainties-Western trade challenges, risk-averse lenders shunning private borrowers...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are also uncertainties regarding Chinas future growth model, stemming from Western challenges to Chinese participation in the global trading system and the inconsistencies between the old and new policy playbooks. Risk-averse lenders shun private-sector borrowers because of a lack of good collateral and the implicit guarantees on loans to the state sector.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which just strengthens the state sector even more, creating these negative feedback loops.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which just strengthens the state sector even more, creating these negative feedback loops.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These uncertainties, in turn, create negative feedback loops. The role of the state naturally strengthens as the government tries to stabilize growth rates at lower levels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then you've got high real estate prices forcing consumers to borrow more, which crowds out spending on other things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you've got high real estate prices forcing consumers to borrow more, which crowds out spending on other things.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A lack of alternative financial assets channels savings into the property market, but high-real estate prices force consumers to borrow more to buy property, crowding out consumption.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, the near-term risk of a crash is low—China has fiscal and regulatory tools to stabilize things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, the near-term risk of a crash is low-China has fiscal and regulatory tools to stabilize things.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be clear, the near-term risk of a Chinese crash or crisis remains low. Despite higher debt levels, China retains plenty of fiscal and regulatory tools to stabilize its economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But accidents can happen, especially with exchange-rate management being such a delicate issue right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But accidents can happen, especially with exchange-rate management being such a delicate issue right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, as with any major policy shift, the risk of accidents is substantial. The greatest risk concerns exchange-rate management, which is currently preventing China from using monetary policy to help stimulate the economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: How they handle this transition is gonna have major implications, not just for China but for global stability too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: How they handle this transition is gonna have major implications, not just for China but for global stability too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: How its leaders manage this transition is crucial for Chinas future, and how well it performs its balancing act will have major implications for global stability.
